content.rendered:
From colorful and abstract to black-and-white and figurative, plenty of range this week with work from Brooklyn, Oslo, and London.

Sauvage by Triboro

Sauvage is a restaurant that serves “French-accented American fare and cocktails in a crisp bistro setting” in Brooklyn, NY. Its identity, by local firm Triboro, revolves around a lively mélange of abstract shapes and colors that feel like the baby we never knew we wanted of mid-century modern and tropical-Tiki-something. What they are, what they mean, doesn’t really matter as they are full of explosive, visual joy. The shapes stand in stark contrast with the literally minimal logo in a hand-written, super spaced out wordmark — a typographic style that runs throughout the menus as well. It’s all an odd combination of elements but it works quite well. See full project

Sentralen by Metric Design

Sentralen is a center for culture and innovation in Oslo, Norway, housed in a 115-year-old building previously occupied by a bank and now offers its six halls for rent for a variety of events and performances. The identity by local firm Metric Design, picks up where the bank, Sparebanken, left off by using their 1930s logo as a starting point to develop a custom logo with a Blackletter-lite aesthetic. The result is a great mix of old and new — just like the building and its new tenant — with a strong rhythm to it. Based on the logo and materials of the bank, Metric Design also created a custom type family in collaboration with Ellmer Stefan that is then deployed across all materials and wayfinding. The overall look is effectively unified by typography, with special bursts of awesome in those numbers. See full project

Carpenters Wharf by Jack Renwick Studio

Carpenters Wharf is a new apartment building in the creative and artistic enclave of Fish Island, London. Reflecting the industrial history of the area and specifically that the site was previously used by a furniture maker, London-based Jack Renwick Studio built an identity around the textures of locally-sourced wood that was inked, printed, and scanned. The textures are masked inside a bevy of geometric arrangements and paired with a sturdy sans serif. The mix feels both rugged and luxurious and some of the type and image combinations are absolutely winning. In a nice twist I like how the type and textures are rendered in white where you would expect it to be black or dark and I love how the wood textures are transparent, allowing the photos to seep through. See full project
